metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Cosmic-ray observation system of soil moisture of Daman Superstation, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from a Cosmic-ray Soil Moisture Observing System of soil moisture of Daman Superstation from January 1 to December 31, 2021. The site (100.372° E, 38.856° N) was located on a cropland (maize surface) in the Daman irrigation, which is near Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556 m. The bottom of the probe was 0.5 m above the ground; the sampling interval was 1 hour.
The raw COSMOS data include the following: battery (Batt, V), temperature (T, ℃), relative humidity (RH, %), air pressure (P, hPa), fast neutron counts (N1C, counts per hour), thermal neutron counts (N2C, counts per hour), sample time of fast neutrons (N1ET, s), and sample time of thermal neutrons (N2ET, s). The distributed data include the following variables: Date, Time, P, N1C, N1C_cor (corrected fast neutron counts) and VWC (volume soil moisture, %), which were processed as follows:
1) Data were removed and replaced by -6999 when (a) the battery voltage was less than 11.8 V, (b) the relative humidity was greater than 80% inside the probe box, (c) the counting data were not of one-hour duration and (d) neutron count differed from the previous value by more than 20%; 2) An air pressure correction was applied to the quality-controlled raw data according to the equation contained in the equipment manual; 3) After the quality control and corrections were applied, soil moisture was calculated using the equation in Zreda et al. (2012), where N0 is the neutron counts above dry soil and the other variables are fitted constants that define the shape of the calibration function. Here, the parameter N0 was calibrated using the in situ observed soil moisture by SoilNET within the footprint; 4) Based on the calibrated N0 and corrected N1C, the hourly soil moisture was computed using the equation from the equipment manual. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Zhu et al. (2015) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

background: The acquisition of regional surface soil moisture has long been a research challenge. In recent years, the use of cosmic ray fast neutron methods to measure regional surface soil moisture has made significant progress. As a novel non-destructive measurement method for medium-scale soil moisture, the cosmic ray fast neutron method can obtain soil moisture within a source area of about 300 meters in radius. The larger measurement source area fills the gap between traditional point observations and remote sensing large-area observations. Traditional measurement methods include: gravimetric method (oven-drying method), neutron gauge method, capacitance method, tensiometer method, time-domain reflectometry (TDR), and frequency-domain reflectometry (FDR). These measurement methods are all destructive and point-based, with measurement scales mostly at small scales, poor spatial representativeness, and difficulty in obtaining information on the regional distribution of soil moisture. The feasibility study of remote sensing monitoring of soil moisture began in the 1960s, with applied research starting in the mid-1970s. Remote sensing technology allows for rapid and large-area monitoring of soil moisture, but the soil moisture obtained through remote sensing is an average value at the pixel scale, with spatial resolutions generally ranging from tens of meters (aerial remote sensing) to tens of kilometers (satellite remote sensing). Moreover, it only provides instantaneous values at the time of aircraft or satellite overpass, making it impossible to obtain continuous data, which limits the application of large-scale remote sensing measurements in actual soil moisture monitoring. There is a gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing monitoring, which is the inability to obtain regional soil moisture information at the scale of farmland or small watersheds. Similarly, it is not possible to obtain the required pixel-scale soil moisture data during the validation of remotely sensed soil moisture retrievals. In recent years, research on measuring surface soil moisture using cosmic ray fast neutrons has gradually attracted attention. The intensity of cosmic ray fast neutrons above the surface is inversely related to soil moisture content. By setting up a neutron probe above the surface to measure the intensity of cosmic ray fast neutrons, surface soil moisture content can be retrieved. The cosmic ray fast neutron method is a passive, non-invasive medium-scale soil moisture measurement method, with a measurement radius of about 300 meters and an effective measurement depth of 12 to 76 cm.
research objective: This article utilizes cosmic ray instruments to conduct long-term continuous monitoring of soil moisture in the farmland of the Zhangye area in the middle reaches of the Heihe River, and compares the results with data from Wireless Sensor Networks (WSN) to analyze the reliability of cosmic ray observations. The article analyzes the results of regional soil moisture observation experiments conducted in the Zhangye oasis farmland, indicating that the cosmic ray soil moisture observation system can effectively obtain regional soil moisture content. It not only accurately captures long-term time series soil moisture at the farmland scale but also provides meaningful ground validation data for remote sensing inversion of soil moisture.
challenges: There is a gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale monitoring through remote sensing, which makes it difficult to obtain regional soil moisture information at the scale of farmland or small watersheds. Similarly, in the process of validating soil moisture retrieved from remote sensing, it is challenging to obtain the required pixel-scale soil moisture data. Hydrogen atoms in the cosmic ray source region are not only present in soil moisture but also exist in lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor. The presence of these hydrogen atom sources inevitably affects the propagation of fast neutrons. Zreda et al. pointed out that the presence of lattice water reduces the detection depth of cosmic rays; however, under the assumption that lattice water and soil organic matter remain constant, these effects can be eliminated through a one-time field soil moisture calibration in the source area. In sparsely vegetated areas, the influence of vegetation can also be eliminated based on field soil moisture calibration, but under rapidly growing vegetation, the moisture content of the vegetation has a certain impact on observations, and there is currently no comprehensive method to correct for this. The presence of water vapor affects the measurement source area of cosmic rays, and MCNPX simulations indicate that the detection radius under saturated water vapor is about 10% lower than that under dry air.
methods: The datasets used in this article are all derived from the 2012 "Heihe River Basin Eco-Hydrological Comprehensive Remote Sensing Observation Experiment," which mainly includes cosmic ray soil moisture datasets, wireless sensor network datasets (Soil-NET part), and rainfall datasets (Daman Station). During soil moisture observation, only a fast neutron probe needs to be installed; at the beginning of this experiment, only one fast neutron probe was installed for soil moisture observation. This article utilizes cosmic ray instruments to conduct long-term continuous monitoring of soil moisture in the farmland of the Zhangye area in the middle reaches of the Heihe River and compares it with soil moisture wireless sensor network data (Wireless Sensor Network, WSN) to study the reliability of the cosmic ray observation results.
dataset: The cosmic ray soil moisture dataset mainly includes raw fast neutron data, raw atmospheric pressure data, etc., with a sampling frequency of 1 hour. Fast neutron data can be used to infer soil moisture information in the study area. SoilNET mainly contains observation data from 50 SoilNET soil moisture/temperature nodes located within the MODIS pixel of the Daman Super Station. Each node can connect to four SISOMOP (Simple Soil Moisture Probe) soil moisture/temperature probes, which measure soil moisture and temperature at depths of 4, 10, 20, and 40 cm, with 19 of them distributed within the cosmic ray source area. The sampling frequency of SoilNET nodes is 10 minutes. This paper primarily uses SoilNET node soil moisture data to validate cosmic ray observation results, requiring the aggregation of the original 10-minute data into 1-hour data for synchronization with cosmic ray data. The rainfall dataset (Daman Super Station) mainly includes raw rainfall data, with a sampling frequency of 10 minutes. During use, the original data needs to be aggregated into 1-hour data to analyze the relationship between cosmic ray soil moisture changes and rainfall.
findings: The cosmic ray soil moisture observation system can effectively obtain regional soil moisture content, not only accurately capturing long-term time series soil moisture at the farmland scale but also providing genuinely meaningful surface validation data for remote sensing inversion of soil moisture. Comparisons show that cosmic rays reflect a surface-level change in soil moisture, which can effectively indicate the trend of soil moisture changes beneath the farmland surface. After excluding irrigation period data, the correlation coefficient significantly increased to 0.86, and the RMSE decreased to 0.028 m³/m³.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure regional soil moisture in arid areas?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to measure regional soil moisture in arid areas is the cosmic-ray neutron method. This method involves using cosmic-ray instruments to measure fast neutron intensity above the ground, which is inversely related to soil moisture content. It allows for non-invasive, medium-scale soil moisture measurements with a measurement radius of approximately 300 meters.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when measuring soil moisture in oasis-desert systems using traditional methods?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced when measuring soil moisture in oasis-desert systems using traditional methods is the spatial representativeness of point measurements. Traditional methods like gravimetric or neutron probe techniques are point-based, leading to difficulties in capturing regional soil moisture distribution. These methods have smaller measurement scales and poor spatial representation, which limits their effectiveness in providing comprehensive soil moisture information for larger areas.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in an oasis-desert area?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that includes long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in an oasis-desert area is the collection of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems. This dataset, available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, includes fluxes of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane, along with auxiliary hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021, acquired using systems like eddy covariance and scintillometers.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of energy and carbon flux measurement?
Definition.Answer: The 'eddy covariance system' is a methodological approach used to measure the turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane between the land surface and the atmosphere. It captures half-hourly data on these fluxes, providing insights into the energy and carbon exchange processes in ecosystems such as oasis-desert systems. The system typically includes sensors for wind speed, air temperature, and gas concentrations, and is used in conjunction with supplementary hydrometeorological data and automatic weather stations.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of cosmic ray neutron sensing for soil moisture measurement compare to traditional point measurement methods in terms of spatial coverage and invasiveness?
Comparison.Answer: Cosmic ray neutron sensing is a passive, non-invasive method that covers a larger spatial area with a measurement radius of approximately 300 m and an effective depth of 12 to 76 cm, filling the gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing. Traditional methods like weighing, neutron probe, and TDR offer smaller, often invasive point measurements with limited spatial representativeness.

Interpretation.Question: How do data processing and quality control procedures impact the reliability and accuracy of soil moisture measurements collected using cosmic-ray neutron methods?
Interpretation.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedures, such as data filtering and pressure correction, ensure the reliability and accuracy of measurements by removing erroneous data, correcting for atmospheric pressure variations, and calibrating soil moisture calculations through empirical methods.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in using cosmic-ray neutron techniques for soil moisture measurement in environments with varying vegetation and atmospheric conditions?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include the influence of hydrogen atoms from sources like vegetation and atmospheric water vapor, which can affect neutron propagation and measurement. These factors can cause measurement errors unless adjusted for through field calibration or empirical corrections.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can a combination of remote sensing and in-situ measurements, such as those from cosmic-ray neutron probes, enhance the understanding of regional soil moisture distribution?
Interpretation.Answer: Combining remote sensing with in-situ measurements allows for validation and calibration of satellite data with ground observations, bridging the gap between different spatial scales and providing a comprehensive understanding of soil moisture distribution over large areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the gap between traditional point measurement methods and remote sensing in obtaining regional soil moisture information?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The gap is caused by the limited spatial representativeness of traditional point measurement methods, which are often invasive and provide small-scale data, while remote sensing offers larger-scale measurements that are temporally discontinuous and lack the necessary resolution for field or small watershed scales.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the cosmic-ray neutron method considered effective for measuring soil moisture over a mid-scale area?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The cosmic-ray neutron method is effective because it is a passive, non-invasive technique that can measure soil moisture over a large area, approximately 300 meters in radius, bridging the gap between small-scale point measurements and large-scale remote sensing data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in correcting cosmic-ray neutron data for soil moisture measurements?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in correcting cosmic-ray neutron data arise from the presence of hydrogen atoms not only in soil moisture but also in lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor, which can affect the neutron count and require specific calibration to account for variations in these sources.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using cosmic-ray neutron methods for soil moisture measurement in terms of data reliability and validation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of cosmic-ray neutron methods for soil moisture measurement can provide reliable data for regional soil moisture with long-term sequence monitoring. This method effectively fills the gap between traditional point-based measurements and large-scale remote sensing, providing true surface validation data for remote sensing inversion of soil moisture. However, challenges include the presence of hydrogen atoms in various sources, such as soil organic matter and vegetation, which can affect neutron propagation and measurement accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What challenges arise from the need to correct cosmic-ray neutron data for environmental factors like pressure and humidity, and how do these challenges affect data accuracy?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Correcting cosmic-ray neutron data for environmental factors such as pressure and humidity is essential for accurate soil moisture measurements. These corrections are necessary because environmental conditions can significantly influence neutron counts. For instance, high humidity can affect the measurement area by reducing the detection radius. Accurate calibration and correction are required to ensure data accuracy, but challenges include accounting for rapidly changing vegetation moisture content and varying environmental conditions that may not have established correction methods.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of using cosmic-ray neutron sensors for soil moisture measurement in arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of using cosmic-ray neutron sensors for soil moisture measurement is to obtain a continuous and accurate long-term series of soil moisture data at the farm scale. This method fills the gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing, providing crucial area-based soil moisture data to support remote sensing validation and regional soil moisture monitoring.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to correct cosmic-ray neutron data for pressure and calibrate with local soil samples?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Correcting cosmic-ray neutron data for pressure and calibrating with local soil samples is important to ensure the reliability and accuracy of soil moisture measurements. The pressure correction accounts for atmospheric variations affecting neutron counts, while calibration with local soil samples adjusts for factors like lattice water and organic matter, which can influence neutron propagation.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the long-term goals of collecting data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The long-term goals of collecting data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems include understanding the interactions between these systems and maintaining their ecological stability. This data supports the goals of carbon peaking and neutrality, as well as sustainable development and ecological security in oasis regions by providing a quantitative understanding of these exchanges.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in calibrating the cosmic ray instruments for accurate soil moisture measurement in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The calibration involves determining N0, which is the fast neutron count under dry soil conditions. This requires comparing the cosmic ray data with actual soil moisture obtained from soil samples or dense wireless sensor networks. The calibration aims to adjust for variables like lattice water and vegetation that may affect neutron readings.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is data quality ensured during the collection of soil moisture information using cosmic ray neutron probes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data quality is ensured by implementing a series of data screening criteria: excluding data when voltage is below 11.8 V, relative humidity is above 80%, sampling intervals deviate from 60±1 minutes, and when the fast neutron count changes drastically compared to adjacent hours. Missing or invalid data is replaced with -6999.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to correct cosmic ray neutron data for atmospheric pressure variations in soil moisture studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The cosmic ray neutron data is corrected for atmospheric pressure variations using a formula provided in the instrument's manual. This correction adjusts the fast neutron count to account for changes in air pressure, ensuring more accurate soil moisture readings.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods and instruments enable the monitoring of soil moisture in arid and semi-arid regions like the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin?
Enablement.Answer: The use of cosmic-ray neutron sensors allows for non-invasive, medium-scale monitoring of soil moisture. These sensors measure the intensity of cosmic-ray neutrons above the surface, which inversely correlates with soil moisture content. The dataset includes cosmic-ray neutron soil moisture data, wireless sensor network data, and other hydrometeorological parameters.

Enablement.Question: How does integrating wireless sensor networks enhance the reliability of soil moisture data collection in agricultural oases?
Enablement.Answer: Wireless sensor networks (WSN) provide high-frequency data from multiple soil moisture and temperature nodes spread across a region. By comparing the cosmic-ray neutron data with WSN data, researchers can validate the reliability of the cosmic-ray observations, ensuring accurate long-term monitoring of soil moisture at both field and regional scales.

Enablement.Question: What challenges do researchers face when using cosmic-ray neutron sensors for soil moisture monitoring, and what conditions or adjustments enable accurate data correction?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include interference from hydrogen atoms not in soil moisture, such as those in lattice water, organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor. Accurate data correction is enabled by field calibration of soil moisture in the source area, considering constant organic content and lattice water. In sparse vegetation areas, these effects can be corrected based on soil moisture calibration, though rapid vegetation growth poses a correction challenge.

Expectation.Question: Why might the cosmic ray neutron method be expected to provide a more comprehensive measurement of regional soil moisture compared to traditional point measurement methods?
Expectation.Answer: The cosmic ray neutron method can cover a larger measurement area with a radius of approximately 300 m, bridging the gap between point measurements and large-scale remote sensing observations. It is a passive, non-invasive technique that provides spatially representative soil moisture data, unlike traditional methods which are often limited to small-scale and lack spatial representation.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in using cosmic ray neutron measurements for soil moisture monitoring in regions with variable vegetation and soil conditions?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges include the presence of hydrogen atoms in sources other than soil moisture, such as lattice water, organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor, which can affect neutron propagation. In areas with varying vegetation, such as fast-growing plants, the vegetation water content can impact observations, and there is currently no perfect method to correct for these effects.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of wireless sensor network data be expected to enhance the reliability of soil moisture measurements obtained through cosmic ray neutron observations?
Expectation.Answer: Wireless sensor networks (WSN) provide high-frequency soil moisture data at multiple depths, which can be used to validate and enhance the reliability of cosmic ray neutron observations. By comparing WSN data with neutron measurements, researchers can assess and adjust for potential discrepancies, ensuring more accurate long-term monitoring of soil moisture at the field scale.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using cosmic-ray neutron probes for measuring soil moisture in terms of bridging the gap between point-scale and large-scale remote sensing observations?
Judgmental.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron probes are highly effective for measuring soil moisture as they provide a mid-scale measurement with a radius of about 300 m, filling the gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing. They offer non-invasive and continuous monitoring, which is advantageous for regional soil moisture assessment and validation of remote sensing data.

Judgmental.Question: What are the challenges associated with correcting cosmic-ray neutron data for hydrogen sources other than soil moisture, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The presence of hydrogen atoms in sources other than soil moisture, such as lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor, poses challenges in cosmic-ray neutron data correction. These challenges can be addressed through field soil moisture calibration to mitigate the effects of invariant factors like lattice water and organic matter. However, vegetation moisture content, especially in rapidly growing areas, remains difficult to correct accurately, and no comprehensive method currently exists for this correction.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways do you think data collection methods for soil moisture using cosmic-ray neutron systems could be improved to enhance data reliability and spatial coverage?
Judgmental.Answer: Improving data collection methods for cosmic-ray neutron systems could involve integrating additional sensors for environmental parameters to enhance data reliability, such as soil moisture wireless sensor networks for validation. Increasing the spatial density of neutron probe installations could further enhance spatial coverage. Additionally, developing advanced calibration techniques to account for variable vegetation and atmospheric conditions could improve the accuracy of soil moisture estimations.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure why conventional soil moisture measurement approaches are inadequate for regional monitoring.
Assertion.Answer: Conventional soil moisture measurement methods, such as gravimetric or neutron probe methods, are typically point-based and invasive, offering limited spatial representation. They fail to provide comprehensive regional soil moisture distribution information, which is essential for understanding broader environmental and agricultural dynamics. Cosmic ray neutron methods, however, offer a broader measurement area without the need for direct soil contact.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the data processing steps required to ensure the accuracy of neutron count measurements for soil moisture estimation.
Assertion.Answer: Data processing for neutron count measurements involves several steps to ensure accuracy, such as data screening to remove unreliable data based on voltage, humidity, and sampling interval criteria. Additional steps include pressure correction using specific formulas from the instrument's manual and instrument calibration to account for local dry soil conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline a comprehensive approach to enhance the reliability of soil moisture data collection using cosmic-ray neutron probes in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: To enhance the reliability of soil moisture data collection using cosmic-ray neutron probes, the approach should involve long-term continuous monitoring and comparison with wireless sensor network data to study observational reliability. Data should be collected with an hourly sampling frequency, and additional measures like data calibration using local soil samples can be implemented. The methodology should also consider filtering data based on criteria such as voltage, relative humidity, and sampling intervals to ensure data quality.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose a strategy to integrate remote-sensing data with field observations for soil moisture analysis in arid environments.
Request/Directive.Answer: A strategy to integrate remote-sensing data with field observations for soil moisture analysis could involve using cosmic-ray neutron probe data to provide ground validation for remote-sensing retrievals. This would require setting up neutron probes to obtain soil moisture data over a radius of about 300 meters, and calibrating these measurements with soil samples from the region. The integration would help bridge the gap between point measurements from traditional methods and large-scale observations from remote sensing, enhancing spatial representation and accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please develop a framework to address the challenges of measuring soil moisture in oasis–desert ecosystems using both traditional and advanced methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: A framework to address the challenges in measuring soil moisture in oasis–desert ecosystems should combine traditional methods like gravimetric analysis and TDR with advanced methods such as cosmic-ray neutron probes. The framework would include steps for calibrating neutron probe data against traditional point measurements and involve continuous monitoring to capture temporal dynamics. Addressing challenges such as interference from hydrogen atoms in organic matter and vegetation would require careful data correction and validation through field calibration procedures. Additionally, the framework should include protocols for data sharing and processing to facilitate comprehensive analysis.
